objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer

objinfo.objorder: These 11 proof impressions (Bentley Plates 1, 2, 4-7, 9-11, 17, 18) were at one time bound, but their order is unknown.See the Editors' Notes for the state of each plate.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.1 x 16.4 cm. and 23.9 x 17.3 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 8Objects 3/4, 5/6, and 9/10 (Bentley Plates 4/5, 6/7, and 11/17) are printed recto/verso. The remaining 5 plates are printed on individual leaves. The recto/verso printing of Objects 9 and 10 (Bentley Plates 11 and 17) suggests that, at an early stage in its development, *Europe* included that sequence of plates. See A. W. J. Lincoln, "Blake's 'Europe': An Early Version?," *Notes and Queries*, n.s. 25.3 (June 1978): 213.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 30.0 x 23.8 cm. and 33.5 x 26.7 cm.See the Editors' Notes for the leaf size of each object.
objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with some pen and ink outlining on Object 11 (Bentley Plate 18)
objinfo.inkcolor: blue (Object 1, Bentley Plate 1) and slightly varying shades of blue-green
objinfo.stabholes: 5The holes are 2.0 cm. from the top and 10.2, 6.6, 6.8, and 6.8 apart.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably the copy sold from the collection of John Giles, Christie's, 2 Feb. 1881, lot 184, "8 engraved leaves, with a duplicate of the frontispiece, coloured" (£3.3s. to the dealer E. Parsons & Sons); Alexander Sykes, sold from his collection at Sotheby's, 29 July 1936, lot 1006, apparently unbound "in a portfolio," the "duplicate of the frontispiece" noted in the 1881 auction catalogue no longer included (£26 to the dealer James Rimmell & Sons); sold by Rimmell in Nov. 1936 for £250 to the British Museum.

objnote.p: This is the only recorded impression of the first state (of two). An abraded area above the figure's back suggests that some lines, perhaps picturing his upper right arm drawn back, were removed. The leaf measures 33.0 x 26.2 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, on the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Although partly erased, lines above his back may picture his right upper arm drawn back behind his body. Slight indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. Beams of light emanate from the circle, surrounded by clouds except where the man's arm extends downward. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

component.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, on the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Although partly erased, lines above his back may picture his upper right arm, drawn back behind his body. Slight indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."
The figure kneels within a circle or sphere, perhaps the sun from which beams of light emanate.
The figure holds dividers or compasses.
The figure and the disc in which he squats are surrounded by clouds except where his left arm descends.
The horizontal position of the figure's hair and beard suggest a strong wind blowing from right to left.

objnote.p: This impression is in the only known state. The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. A giant snake is coiled just above the imprint. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. A small crest rises from the top of its head. Its mouth is open; both its long forked tongue and teeth are prominent. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" in the imprint. The mottled pattern on the snake's body suggests scales. Below the two large coils of its lower body and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves. The washes behind the snake's coils suggest clouds, hills, or mountains. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant snake is coiled just above the imprint. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. A small spiky crest rises from the top of its head. Its mouth is open; both its long forked tongue and teeth are prominent. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" (line 5) in the imprint. The mottled pattern on the snake's body suggests scales. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

Below the two large coils of the snake's lower body and right of "Lambeth" (line 4) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves. There may be slight indications of more vegetation below the snake on the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with three loops extends from the top of the first letter of the first word ("Europe" [line 1]) in the title. A vine with one loop, and perhaps leaves at its end, extends horizontally beneath "Europe" from its third letter.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with three loops extends from the top of the first letter of the first word ("Europe" [line 1]) in the title.
A vine with one loop, and perhaps leaves at its end, extends horizontally beneath "Europe" (line 1) from its third letter.

lg.l: EUROPE
a
PROPHECY
LAMBETH
Printed by Will: Blake: 1794

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of three). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures appear in the landscape above the text. A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and his legs crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm and index finger on his left hand pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left. This figure on the left is a youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest. He strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler. Below his feet is a path or road. Right and left of this walking figure, and above the cave with the assassin, are the leaves of plants or trees. There are also the leaves of plants below the traveler and possibly below and to the right of the cave.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and his legs crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm and index finger on his left hand pointing up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. His mouth is drawn into an evil smile. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left.

A youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest, strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler.
The figure with a dagger crouches within a cave formed of large stones.
The walking figure strides forward on a road or path.

Vegetation, probably the leaves of plants or trees, surrounds the walking figure and extends above the cave in which the crouching figure sits. There is also undifferentiated vegetation at the base of the cave on the right. The large leaves left of the cave may be oak leaves.
The leaves of a plant appear below the traveler.
Vegetative forms, perhaps the leaves of a plant, appear right of the crouching figure's feet near the right margin of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression and perhaps with eyes closed. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings. Ten birds fly near the figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing. Further to the right, a nude male falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his hands or arms, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.

component.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing directly at us, with a pained or despairing expression and perhaps with eyes closed. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's arms and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings.

A nude male falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his arms or hands, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?). This weight apparently pulls him downwards.
A large weight is attached to the arms or hands of the descending figure, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?).
Ten birds fly near the bat-winged figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a good deal of interlinear decoration, particularly in the margins of the text. Most consists of vines and leaves, but there are also a few animals. The first letter of the first word in line 2 twists into a spiral vine on the left; it (or another, detached vine) descends with one further loop in the left margin to line 10. A long, wavy vine extends between lines 4 and 5. On it is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 5. Further to the left, under the first word of line 4, is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly. A vine trails downward from this same first word ("And") in line 4. Just left of the beginning of line 13 is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort. In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 16). In the right margin, another branch of the vine extending between lines 4 and 5 descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. It bears loops, at least two types of leaves, and perhaps some fruit or flowers. A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of this vine (opposite line 4); a worm (note the reticulations) or caterpillar inches its way across the upper reaches of a large, slender leaf opposite the space between lines 8 and 9. Other branches of this vine extend above the falling figure and intertwine with the large leaf to the right of this same figure. To the right are two flying birds. A separate vine with spiky leaves twists right of lines 5 and 6, growing from the "d" in "thunder." Below one of its tendrils, and just to the right of line 8, is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly. A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 7; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 8.

component.illusobjdesc: A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of the vine in the far right margin, right of the space between lines 4 and 5 of the text.
A worm (perhaps an inch worm) or caterpillar (note the reticulations) rises above the large vine right of the space between lines 8 and 9.
Far to the right of lines 14-15, between the long leaves and the edge of the plate, are two flying birds.
The first letter of the first word, line 2 of the text, twists into a spiral vine on the left. It (or another, detached vine) extends with one further loop in the left margin to line 10.
A long vine—a branch of the main vine in the right margin—extends horizontally between lines 4 and 5 of the text.
A vine trails downward from the first word ("And") in line 4.
In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 16).

In the right margin of the text, a loopy vine with leaves of at least two types (including very long ones) and perhaps flowers and/or fruit descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. A branch with spiky leaves extends above the falling figure; another branch is intertwined with the long leaf right of this figure.
A vine with three tendrils or branches and perhaps some spiky leaves twists right of lines 5 and 6 of the text, growing from the "d" in "thunder."
A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 7 of the text; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 8.
On the long vine running between lines 4 and 5 of the text is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 5.
Under the first word of line 4 of the text is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly.
To the left of the beginning of line 14 in the text is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort, or possibly a flower.
To the right of line 8 of the text is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly.

lg.l: The nameless shadowy female rose from out the breast of Orc:
Her snaky hair brandishing in the winds of Enitharmon;
And thus her voice arose.
O mother Enitharmon wilt thou bring forth other sons?
To cause my name to vanish, that my place may not be found.
For I am faint with travel!
Like the dark cloud disburdend in the day of dismal thunder.
My roots are brandish'd in the heavens, my fruits in earth beneath
Surge, foam, and labour into life, first born & first consum'd!
Consumed and consuming!
Then why shouldst thou accursed mother bring me into life?
I wrap my turban of thick clouds around my lab'ring head;
And fold the sheety waters as a mantle round my limbs.
Yet the red sun and moon,
And all the overflowing stars rain down prolific pains.

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state (of two). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design showing four nude males hovering in the sky or on clouds. The two text panels are shaped like clouds. Upper right, we see a figure from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair may be curly. Below is a group of three wrestling figures, all nude and bald. The central figure has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. This central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the left has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. The wrestler on the right has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. All three figures have caricature-like facial expressions suggesting fear and pain (figures right and left) or desperation and cruelty (central figure).

component.illusobjdesc: Upper right, we see a nude from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair may be curly.
A group of three wrestlers, all nude and bald males, hovers in the sky.

The central bald (or almost bald), nude and muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent (if somewhat abstractly rendered) genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand.

The figure on the left in the group of three nude and bald male wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror, and his mouth is slightly open.

The wrestler on the right in the group of three nude and bald males has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His head is bent back as he is being strangled, and his mouth is slightly open; his face expresses pain and terror.

The two text areas are shaped like, and perhaps are supposed to represent, clouds. These clouds extend to the right margin below the figure upper right. Dark clouds appear below the text, where the wrestling figures are backed by a dark and perhaps stormy sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative and avian motifs decorate the text. A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 2. A similar vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 13. A spiky vine with tendrils or branches hovers above "my voice" in line 16. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine. Two birds fly above " vig'rous progeny" in line 8, a flock of four birds flies right of line 11, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 13, and a flock of three birds follows line 15. The edge of the etching border caught some ink left of lines 5-10 in this copy, but this vine-like patch is probably not intentionally representational.

component.illusobjdesc: Two birds fly above "vig'rous progeny" in line 8 of the text, a flock of four birds flies right of line 11, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 13, and a flock of three birds follows line 15.
A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 2 of the text.
A vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 13 of the text.
A spiky vine with tendrils or branches hovers above "my voice" in line 16 of the text. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine.

lg.l: Unwilling I look up to heaven! unwilling count the stars!
Sitting in fathomless abyss of my immortal shrine.
I sieze their burning power
And bring forth howling terrors, all devouring fiery kings.
Devouring & devour'ed roaming on dark and desolate mountains
In forests of eternal death, shrieking in hollow trees.
Ah mother Enitharmon!
Stamp not with solid form this vig'rous progeny of fires.
I bring forth from my teeming bosom myriads of flames.
And thou dost stamp them with a signet, then they roam abroad
And leave me void as death;
Ah! I am drown'd in shady woe, and visionary joy.
And who shall bind the infinite with an eternal band?
To compass it with swaddling bands? and who shall cherish it
With milk and honey?
I see it smile & I roll inward & my voice is past.
She ceast & rolld her shady clouds
Into the secret place.

objnote.p: This impression is in the only known state. The leaf measures 33.5 x 26.0 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text and a great deal of interlinear decoration, the major pictorial motifs—the sky and the two largest figures—constitute a full-plate design. The three text panels are shaped like, and may represent, clouds floating in the sky. The largest figure, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (plate 4, line 2) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (plate 4, line 13). Below her cascading hair is a nude, youthful male in a contracted posture. He seems confined by the circle in which he sits. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. It may be a planet. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. He faces forward. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 4), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (plate 5, line 8). The other motifs on this plate, including many human figures, will be treated as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: The largest figure on the plate, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (plate 4, line 2) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (plate 4, line 13).

A nude, youthful male in a very contracted posture sits within a circle. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 4), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (plate 5, line 8).

A figure squats or sits within a circle which may be meant to represent a globe. It has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. Hence, this may be a planet. Flames surround the figure within the globe.
The three text panels are shaped like, and may be intended to represent, clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The heading is surrounded by several figures and vegetative motifs. The figures, particularly the larger ones, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate. The lower left corner of "A" (in "A / PROPHECY" [lines 1-2]) grows into a long vine with branches. Standing on this vine, near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female. On the right foot of "A" is a tree, possibly a palm, with branches that bend downward. To the left of the "A" and slightly below it is a male(?) embracing a female. Both hover in the air, with the male on the right and facing to the left. Both have long hair and appear nude, although the woman has a long, snake-like tail of drapery extending from her right leg. The man's body is twisted into a curve, seen from behind. His left arm is raised horizontally and embraces the woman's waist. His right leg is extended horizontally. We also see the woman from behind, with her body twisted into a curve matching the man's. Both her arms are raised horizontally, with her head facing down. These gestures suggest that she is trying to escape from the man. In contrast, the couple right of the letter "A" is embracing mutually and appear to be kissing. The winged male(?), possibly an angel, hovers horizontally in the air, with his arms raised at 45 degrees to embrace the woman(?) who hovers vertically. She too is winged and may be an angel. Her legs are bent back and her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace her companion. He faces down and to the left; she faces up and to the right. Below the "A" is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline. Other cloud outlines extend to the upper right and below "PROPHECY" in the heading. Two figures hover in, or fly through, the air above the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). Both are nude; the upper figure appears to be male, while the lower figure seems to be female. Both have their left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees, and both may be holding something in their right hands. The letters of "PROPHECY" are well decorated with eight human figures and vines. Proceeding from left to right, these include a vine with leaves or lily-like flowers intertwined with the first letter and extending to the second. A small standing figure holds the vertical of the first "P," and a small, indistinct figure dangles from the base of the letter. Another figure stands on the foot of the vertical of the "R" and faces to the left with arms raised vertically. Above this figure is a small form that may be a descending child or infant, arms stretched downward toward the adult. The right foot of the "R" bears a very small seated figure, hunched over and facing to the right. The letter "O" has two vines with lily-like flowers. Standing within the "O" is a figure facing forward and with left arm raised horizontally to hold a shepherd's crook. To the right of this shepherd is a small flock of sheep. Three vines, or perhaps flames, spring from the foot of the second "P." A vine, perhaps with a few leaves, is intertwined with the next three letters ("HEC"). The final vine in this group springs from the foot of the final letter and forms a spiral above and to the right of the letter. This "Y" also bears three human figures. One, seen from behind and with legs spread and arms raised vertically, seems to be climbing, with the right foot on the foot of the "Y" and the left foot on the "C." A small figure, probably male, stands on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" in "PROPHECY" (line 3). He seems to be walking to the left. Finally, the first bend in the vine growing from the right side of the final letter bears a seated figure facing right, with back slightly hunched over and right arm extended to the right knee. This figure holds a book or tablet and is probably reading. Two flames, or perhaps a flame-like plant, spring from the foot of the "Y" on its right side.

component.illusobjdesc: The human figures surrounding the heading, particularly the four largest figures, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate.

Standing on the vine springing from the lower left of the letter "A" (line 1), near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude male(?), hovering in the air, embraces a female with his left arm around her waist. We see him from behind, but his body is twisted into a curve. His hair is long; his right leg is extended horizontally to the left. He faces left.

Below and left of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude female with long hair, facing down and to the left, hovers in the air. She is embraced around the waist by the male(?) to the right. We see her from behind, with her body twisted into a curve like the male's. Although apparently nude from the waist up, a long, snake-like tail of drapery extends from her right leg. Her arms are raised horizontally to the left. This gesture, as well as her head position, suggest that she is trying to flee from the male.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude male(?) hovers horizontally and reaches down, with his arms at 45 degrees, to embrace the female(?) below and to the left. His large wings suggest he may be an angel. He faces down and to the left and may be kissing the female. His hair may be curly.

Right of the "A" in the title (line 1), a nude female(?) hovers in the air. Her large wings suggest she may be an angel. She reaches up with her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace the male(?) hovering horizontally to the right. Her legs are slightly bent. She faces up and to the right and may be kissing the male.

Below the "A" of the heading is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline.

A small figure holds the vertical of the first letter of "PROPHECY" (line 2) in the heading. The figure reaches up with both arms and may be climbing. The figure probably faces forward or to the right.
A figure dangles below the "P" and grasps the base of the letter with vertically raised arms.
A small figure stands, facing left, on the foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). The figure, probably male, has his arms raised vertically, perhaps to catch the small figure above.

Just above the figure standing on the left foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2) is a very small human form, probably a child or infant. This tiny figure descends head-first toward the adult below, with arms reaching downward.
A very small figure sits on the right foot of the letter "R" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). The figure faces right and is slightly hunched over.

A figure, probably male, stands within the "O" of "PROPHECY." He faces forward with his left arm raised horizontally. He holds a shepherd's crook in his left hand. Given the crook and the flock of sheep to the right, the figure is almost certainly a shepherd.

A figure, probably male and seen from behind, climbs between the "C" and "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). His legs are spread, with his left foot poised on the "C" and his right foot just touching the foot of the "Y." He reaches up vertically with both arms to hold the left diagonal of the "Y."
A very small figure, probably male, stands on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" in "PROPHECY" (line 2). He seems to be walking to the left.

A small figure, probably gowned and male, sits on the vine extending from the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). He faces to the right, with his upper body hunched over and his right arm extended at 45 degrees to his knees. He holds, and seems to be reading, a book or tablet.
The figure sitting on the vine extending from the "Y" or "PROPHECY" (line 2) would appear to be holding a book or tablet.

Two figures hover in, or fly through, the air above the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). Both are nude; the upper figure appears to be male, while the lower figure seems to be female. Both have their left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees, and both may be holding something in their right hands. The male’s body is twisted, and his left leg crosses in front of his right leg. The female’s right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep rests within the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) just to the right of their shepherd.
Flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the second "P" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) on its right side.
Two flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2) on its right side.

The outlines of clouds extend above "PROPHECY" (line 2) from the "O" to the upper right corner of the plate; one cloud outline descends between the second "P" and "H" of the word and extends below the word to the "R."
A vine, perhaps with leaves, extends to the left from the left foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading.
The raised arms of the figure standing on the left foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading vegetate into branches that arch downward. This may be a willow.
A small tree with arching branches, perhaps a palm, grows from the right foot of "A" (line 1) in the heading.

A vine with lily-like flowers is intertwined with the left side of the "O" of "PROPHECY" (line 2). A separate vine, or the other end of the same vine, grows up the right side of the same letter. It too bears lily-like flowers.
A vine with one loop and a few leaves is intertwined with the letters "HEC" of "PROPHECY" (line 2).
A vine, with a spiral upper right, grows from the right side of the foot of "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The cloud-like text panel containing lines 3-7 of the text includes three human figures, birds, and some vines. A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 3 and turns to the right over that same line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops. To the right of the second loop sits a gowned(?) and apparently female figure. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees and extended to the right. Above her and to the left is a flock of five birds. Two figures hover in the air right of line 3. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. To the right is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it. To the right of this figure, and above "eternal" in line 5, is a vine. Another vine, with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 7. To the right of this line are two birds, flying upward on extended wings.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably female and possibly wearing a gown, sits on the vine above "deep of" in line 3 of the text. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees.

Two figures hover in the air right of line 3 of the text. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. The hem of her gown forms a twisting tail.

To the right of line 3, and right of the hovering female figure, is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it.
The figure hovering above "eternal" (line 5) holds, and presumably plays, a horn with one loop in it.
A flock of five birds flies on extended wings above the vine extending horizontally above line 3 of the text.
Two birds fly upwards on extended wings right of line 7 of the text.
A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 3 of the text and turns to the right over this same line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops.
A vine curls above "eternal" in line 5 of the text.
A vine, perhaps with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 7 of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures, birds c, a cloud outline, and a vine decorate the third cloud-like text panel containing lines 8-17 of the text. A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 8 and extends above the line to the word "her." A much smaller vine or single leaf grows from the vertical of the last letter in this line. Just above the first word ("Then"), a nude figure (probably male) lies supine on this vine. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body. The figure above may be gowned (note the slight suggestion of trailing drapery) and of uncertain gender. This figure's legs are spread and one arm (the left?) is raised vertically. The figure may be rising in the air. To the right, above "Enitharmon" in line 8, is a flying bird. Another two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 12. A cloud outline (or perhaps the surface of the earth?) below and to the right of the birds bears a figure crawling to the right on all fours. Further to the right, another figure, perhaps female, stands and leans to the left against the cloud outline. Her legs are crossed; she may be wearing tights in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, probably male, lies supine on the vine above the first word ("Then") in line 8 of the text. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body.

A figure, facing left, hovers above the first letter of "Enitharmon" in line 8 of the text. This figure, of uncertain gender, has his or her (left?) arm raised vertically and legs spread. The figure may be gowned (note the slight suggestion of a tail of drapery) and rising.
A figure crawls to the right on all fours along the cloud outline (or surface of the earth?) above the last word ("rest") in line 13 of the text. The figure may be gowned.

A figure, probably female and possibly wearing tights in this copy, stands and leans to the left against a cloud outline. Her upper body, twisted to the left, is braced against the cloud with her left arm; her legs are crossed.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the middle letters of "Enitharmon" (and above the vine), line 8 of the text.
Two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 12 of the text.
A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 8 and extends above the line to the word "her."
The vertical of the final letter of "around," the last word in line 8 of the text, becomes a vine arching over the word. It may terminate in a leaf.
A cloud outline-or possibly the surface of the ground-extends between lines 11 and 12 of the text.

lg.l: The deep of winter came;
What time the secret child,
Descended thro' the orient gates of the eternal day;
War ceas'd, & all the troops like shadows fled
to their abodes.
Then Enitharmon saw her sons & daughters rise around.
Like pearly clouds they meet together in the crystal house;
And Los. possessor of the moon, joy'd in the peaceful night:
Thus speaking while his num'rous sons shook their bright fiery wings
Again the night is come
That strong Urthona takes his rest.
And Urizen unloos'd from chains
Glows like a meteor in the distant north
Stretch forth your hands and strike the elemental strings!
Awake the thunders of the deep,

objnote.p: This is the only recorded impression of the first state (of two). The leaf measures 33.5 x 26.0 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design below the text is dominated by two large figures and five smaller ones. A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground—or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc. Above him, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended and her right bent at the knee under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon. The five much smaller figures above may be her sons and daughters. In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left, head apparently down and resting on the left arm extended horizontally. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion. Similar exhaustion is indicated by the nude figure to the right. This figure is probably female and also lies supine on a cloud. Her body is bent back, with her head, right arm, and right leg dangling downward. Above and to the right is another nude female, sitting or lying supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee. Further to the right is an embracing couple hovering in the air, with the woman on the right. They may be kissing. The nude male, facing right, has his legs spread and his right arm raised horizontally. The female, facing left, is gowned—or at least has a tail of drapery curling over her raised left leg. Her legs are spread apart. Her long hair may be gathered into a bun.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude and youthful male lies prone on the ground— or perhaps on a bed of straw. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc.

Above the youthful male lying prone, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended, her right bent at the knee and drawn up under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon.
Five nude figures fill the sky just below the text. These may be the sons and daughters of Enitharmon.

In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left, head apparently down and resting on the left arm extended horizontally. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion.
A nude figure, probably female, lies supine on a cloud. Her posture suggests erotic exhaustion, with her head bent back and her right arm and right leg dangling downward.

A nude female sits or lies supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and probably has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee.
A nude male, facing right, embraces a female and perhaps kisses her. He hovers in the air, with legs spread. His right arm is raised horizontally.

A partly nude female, facing left, hovers in the air and apparently embraces—and perhaps kisses—the male to the left. Her legs are spread apart and a gown or piece of drapery curves over her left leg, forming a curling tail. Her long hair may be twisted into a bun.
The youthful and nude male lies on the ground—or perhaps a bed of straw.
The large female figure, and the three smaller figures above her on the left, lie or kneel on clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is well decorated with vines, one fairly large human figure, and animals. Right of lines 7-10 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms raised and wrapped around his head. He appears to be bald. Right of line 4 are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird, a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird. Another winged creature, perhaps an insect, flies right of lines 7-8. Left and right of this creature are two vines; the vine on the right is very worm-like. A vine below line 9 includes one loop and a grain tassel on its right end. A grasshopper or locust stands on this vine, facing right. Three winged insects fly above the grain tassel. Another vine appears further to the right, with at least one leaf and three loops. Vines, or extensions of a cloud outline, extend below line 14. A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 17 and a vine grows from the "h" of the next word ("Enitharmon").

component.illusobjdesc: Right of lines 7-10 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down, and his arms bent upward and wrapped around his head. He appears to be bald.
Right of line 4 of the text are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird, a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird.
A winged creature, perhaps an insect such as a moth or beetle, flies right of lines 7-8 of the text.
A grasshopper or locust sits, facing right, on the vine above line 10 of the text.
Three flying insects, perhaps flies or moths, appear below "nights of" in line 9 of the text.
A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 17 of the text.
Two vines appear right of lines 7-8 of the text. The vine on the right is very worm-like.
A vine with one loop and a grain tassel at its right end appears between lines 9 and 10 of the text.
A vine with three loops and one leaf wends its way between lines 9 and 10 of the text, left of the descending figure.
An extension of a cloud outline between lines 14 and 15 of the text takes on the appearance of a vine.
A vine with a single leaf grows from the "h" of "horrent" in line 15 of the text.
A vine, possibly with two or three leaves, grows from the "t" of "Enitharmon," the second word in line 17 of the text.

lg.l: The shrill winds wake!
Till all the sons of Urizen look out and envy Los:
Sieze all the spirits of life and bind
Their warbling joys to our loud strings
Bind all the nourishing sweets of earth
To give us bliss, that we may drink the sparkling wine of Los
And let us laugh at war,
Despising toil and care.
Because the days and nights of joy. in lucky hours renew.
Arise O Orc from thy deep den,
First born of Enitharmon rise!
And we will crown thy head with garlands of the ruddy vine;
For now thou art bound;
And I may see thee in the hour of bliss, my eldest born.
The horrent Demon rose. surrounded with red stars of fire,
Whirling about in furious circles round the immortal fiend.
Then Enitharmon down descended into his red light,
And thus her voice rose to her children, the distant heavens reply.

objnote.p: This is the only recorded impression of the second state (of three). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is an enclosed interior space with a floor and a stone back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate. Above is a large cooking pot with a handle suspended from the top of the fireplace by a rod with a hook in its lower end. Clouds of smoke or steam billow above the pot. In the foreground are three figures. On the left is a gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture. She sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head is down between her knees; her long hair cascades to the ground. The gowned woman on the right sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with a worried or pained expression, perhaps looking at the pot. Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair is curly. A dark shadow slants across the upper half of the scene. The wall behind and to the right of the seated woman is also in shadow. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse. Gray washes indicate shadows on the wall above and to the right of the women.

component.illusobjdesc: Gray washes indicate shadows on the wall above and to the right of the women.

A gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture, sits or squats on the floor with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head his down between her knees; her long hair cascades to the ground.

A gowned woman sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with her neck twisted to the left and with a pained or worried expression on her face. She may be looking at the pot.

Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair is curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

The setting is an enclosed interior space with a floor and a stone back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate.
A large cooking pot hangs above the grate at the end of a rod with a hook at its lower end. Smoke or steam billows above the pot.
The apparently dead child lies on a blanket spread on the floor.
The woman sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair.

objnote.p: This is the only known impression of the first state (of two). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm. The phrase inscribed on the wall is "LORD HAVE MERCY ON US." The "H" of "HAVE" and "Y" of "MERCY" are hidden behind the arms of two of the figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription. Left of the door is a standing, and perhaps walking, figure wearing a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This bellman, as well as the inscription on the door (typical of quarantined houses) can be associated with the theme of plague dominating the design. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out, "Bring out your dead!" Below the bellman on the left are a man and woman. The man, wearing a gown or at least a shirt, appears against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman with his right arm. His face suggests pain or despair; his hair is curly. The gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man. Her hair is long and her right arm is at her side. Her face, with mouth open like her companion’s, expresses despair and perhaps pain, and the limp posture of her body indicates that she may be weak with plague. They may be suffering from the plague. To the right, a gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, her posture expresses the pain and despair indicative of the plague. A shadow, added in wash, cuts diagonally across the background wall and door, top left to lower right.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of four figures—a bellman and three figures with expressions of pain or despair— indicates that this is a picture of the plague. This is confirmed by the inscription on the door in the background, typical of what was written on the doors of quarantined houses during the great plague of London in 1665.

A standing, and perhaps walking, figure wears a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This is a bellman, tolling the time. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out during the plague, "Bring out your dead!"

A male wearing a gown or shirt sits against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm. His hair is curly and his mouth is open. His facial expression indicates pain (from disease?) and despair.

A gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left. A belt appears just below her breasts. Her hair is long and her right arm is at her side. Her limp posture and her face, with mouth open like her companions, express despair and perhaps pain (of disease?).

A gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, her posture indicates pain or despair indicative of disease.
The background of the design is composed of a brick wall with a large wooden door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US" with a cross below the inscription.

lg.l: LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US

component.illusobjdesc: The wooden door in the background wall is inscribed.

lg.l: LORD
AVE MERC
ON US

objnote.p: This is the only recorded impression of the first state (of two). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text panel, shaped like a cloud, are two figures in a cloudy and perhaps stormy environment. A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened at the prospect of coming revolution. A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and left leg bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head is down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around his legs. Her long hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help. The background for the figures is filled with clouds, or possibly smoke. The darkness left and right suggests a night scene.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened by the coming revolution.

A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and left leg bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around the legs. Her long, curled hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help.
The background for the figures is filled with heavy storm clouds, or possibly smoke. The text panel above is shaped like a cloud. The darkness on the left suggests that this may be a night scene.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine, with a shape suggesting a spiral, extends horizontally below "bring the lovely," line 8 of the text. The second letter of "my" in line 7 shows a vine-like extension of the descender, while a vine, or perhaps roots, dangle from the first letter of the first word ("And") in line 12.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine, with a shape suggesting a spiral, extends horizontally below "bring the lovely," line 7 of the text.
The second letter of "my" in line 7 shows a vine-like extension of the descender. A vine, or perhaps roots, dangle from the first letter of the first word ("And") in line 12.

lg.l: Arise O Rintrah eldest born: second to none but Orc:
O lion Rintrah raise thy fury from thy forests black;
Bring Palamabron horned priest, skipping upon the mountains;
And silent Elynittria the silver bowed queen:
Rintrah where hast thou hid thy bride!
Weeps she in desart shades?
Alas my Rintrah! bring the lovely jealous Ocalythron,
Arise my son! bring all thy brethren O thou king of fire.
Prince of the sun I see thee with thy innumerable race:
Thick as the summer stars:
But each ramping his golden mane shakes.
And thine eyes rejoice because of strength O Rintrah furious king.

objnote.p: This impression is in the first state (of two). The leaf measures 33.1 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This text plate contains many interlinear vines, birds, insects, and three snakes. Four or five butterflies appear right of lines 1-4. A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 6. Two vines grow from the first letter of the first word in line 9. Vines, at least three birds, a leaf, and flames decorate the space between lines 5 and 6. A butterfly and two other winged insects, two vines (one may be a worm), and an odd shape that may be two moths flying close together appear between lines 8 and 9. A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 8-19. At least one flower, shaped like a Meadia, grows close to the right margin of the plate, right of line 9. Another such flower appears below and to the left of the first one, right of line 12. On and around this large vine are an inch worm below the last word in line 8, caterpillars (above and to the right of line 14 and right of lines 9-10 and 14-15), a spider (right of line 14), and several flying insects. Five flying insects (at least one a butterfly) follow line 11. A vine descends left of the first word in line 15. A vine with two loops grows from the descender of the last letter of "thy" in line 20. A large bird, possibly an eagle, and three smaller birds or insects fly near the right margin of the plate right of lines 18-20. A vine with many loops fills the considerable space between lines 20 and 21 and descends in the right margin to line 26. On this vine are at least two large and two small caterpillars, an inch-worm, two snails, at least three spiders, several insects with wings folded, and a bird perched near the right margin with its mouth open (because it is singing?). Just to the left and within the loops of the vine is another singing bird, facing left with mouth open. A large moth or butterfly appears below "Antamon" in line 20. A flying insect is pictured far to the right of line 23. Below and to the left is a large bird (possibly an eagle) soaring upwards, with a flock of six birds to the left. The form right of lines 26-30 probably represents the sky. A vine descends from the second letter of "my" in line 25. A vine or plant with leaves and several branches appears right of lines 28-37. Intertwined with this vine is a snake, facing to the left with its mouth open and its forked tongue clearly pictured. Two other snakes, both facing left, appear in the bottom margin. The right-most snake in the lower margin has a clearly pictured tongue. The last letter of the last word in line 34 grows into a vine.

component.illusobjdesc: Four or five butterflies fly right of lines 1-4 of the text.
Two, or perhaps three, birds fly below "warble round" in line 5 of the text.
Two butterflies, and either a very small bird or another winged insect, appear below "wings are my delight," line 8 of the text.
The odd forms below "flames" in line 8 of the text may be two moths flying close together.

An inch worm appears on the vine below the last word in line 8. A caterpillar climbs along the vine right of lines 9-10 of the text. Below the left-most caterpillar is another insect on the vine. A winged insect flies right of this last creature.
Five flying insects, perhaps butterflies, appear right of line 11 of the text.
A caterpillar appears above and to the right of the ending of line 14 of the text. Further to the right are a spider and a flying insect. Another caterpillar appears right of lines 15-16.

Right of line 17 of the text are two flying insects or birds. Another such creature appears near the right margin. A large bird, perhaps an eagle, flies downward right of lines 18- 19. Two very small birds or winged insects appear below the bird, right of line 20.
The space between lines 20 and 21 of the text includes two large caterpillars, an inch-worm, a small spider, a snail, and a flying butterfly.

The space between lines 20 and 21, near the right margin, includes two spiders (one large, one small), three insects of uncertain species with wings folded, a caterpillar, a snail, and a bird perched on a vine, facing up and with its mouth open and probably singing. Just to the left and within the loops of the vine is another singing bird, facing left with mouth open. The bird could also be about to eat one of the insects.

A flock of at least five birds flies right of line 25. Further to the right is a large bird, perhaps an eagle, soaring upwards. Above and to the right of the bird is a flying insect, perhaps a dragonfly with four wings.
A snake is intertwined with the vine in the lower right corner of the plate. It faces left, with mouth open and forked tongue clearly pictured.
Two snakes appear in the lower margin. Both face left with mouths open. The tongue of the right-most snake is clearly pictured.
Several flames appear below and to the right of the last word ("Enitharmon") in line 5 of the text.

Two vines extend from the letter "V" in "Manthu-Varcyon" and branch horizontally between lines 5 and 6 of the text. Both may bear slender leaves. A large leaf with a complex shape, or possibly a winged form of some sort, appears farther to the right, below "the feet of" in line 5 of the text.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 6 of the text.
Two vines spring from the first letter of the first word in line 9 of the text.
A vine—or perhaps a worm—twists above "Leutha," line 9 of the text. A second vine extends horizontally above the last two words in the same line.

A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 8-19 of the text. At least one flower, shaped like a Meadia, grows close to the right margin of the plate, right of line 9. Another such flower appears below and to the left of the first one, right of line 12.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 15 of the text.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 20, and a vine with two loops grows from the descender of the last letter of “thy” in this line.
A vine grows from the last letter of the final word of line 34.
A large vine with many loops extends between lines 20 and 21 of the text. Some tendrils, perhaps with leaves, descend in the right margin to line 26.
A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 22, and from the descender of the second letter of "my" in line 25.

A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 26, from the descender of the first letter in the first "your" of line 28, from the descenders of the second letter of the word "my" in lines 29 and 30, and from the descender of the fifth letter in "every" in line 36.
A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 32.
The odd form right of lines 26-30 apparently represents the sky, possibly with cloud outlines.

A vine grows from the descender of the first letter of the second "your" in line 28, from the descender of the third letter of "thy" in line 31, and from the descender of the descender of the seventh letter of the word "revelry" in line 34.
A vine or plant with leaves and several branches appears in the bottom margin and right of lines 28-37 of the text.

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew.
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul:
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Vorcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round:
Thy golden wings are my delight, & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colour'd bow delights upon thy wings;
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light;
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon, prince of the pearly dew,
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee crystal form.
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love,
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents:
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe:
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha, secret dwellers of dreamful caves,
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black.
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions.
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.
She ceas'd, and all went forth to sport beneath the solemn moonLine 32 was changed in the copper to "She ceas'd, for All were forth at sport" in the second state of the plate.
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs,
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry.
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate, and the angel trumpet blew!The words "and the angel trumpet blew!" were erased from the copper in the second state of the plate.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

objnote.p: This is the only recorded impression of the first state (of three). Pen and black ink lines strengthen the outlines of several motifs in the design, including the genitals, outside outline of the upper left leg and chest, and lower right leg and foot of the man and the upper left arm and left side of the torso of the woman he carries. The leaf measures 33.3 x 26.7 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the child whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is the child's father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. Although the child's hair is short, the gown visible around her legs suggests a female. We see her from behind; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left. The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her skirt or gown and one visible foot dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying. Lower left, on top of the steps, is a fluted and broken pillar.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of three figures may be a family of mother, father, and child.

A nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned down and to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. He carries the limp body of a woman over his right shoulder.

We see a young child from behind. Although the figure's hair is short or medium length, the gown around her legs suggests a female. Her left arm is held by the nude male; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. The fingers of her raised right hand may be slightly spread. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left.

The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a woman—perhaps the child's mother. She may be nude from the waist up, although the pen and ink outlining of the triangular shape above the back of her neck suggests a collar. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her skirt or gown and one visible foot dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying.
The background of the design below the text is composed mostly of a sheet of flames.
Three stone steps, or two steps and a plinth, and a fluted and broken classical pillar appear in the lower left corner of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains a good many vegetative motifs and animals. Three vines extend horizontally between lines 2 and 3. The vine on the left includes a loop and one ivy-like leaf. The next vine to the right bears two oak or grape leaves. The largest vine, furthest to the right, has long, slender leaves. At least four insects, perhaps beetles and one caterpillar, crawl on it. Three winged insects (one little more than a dot) and one butterfly (below "fury" in line 2) fly near the vine. Below "of his" in line 2, a bird perches on the vine but spreads its wings as if about to fly into the air. An oak or grape leaf descends from the first word in line 3 and into the far left margin. A vine with ivy-like leaves extends horizontally between lines 8 and 9, divides into several branches in the right margin, and has one branch arching back to the left at line 6. A branch bearing five oak leaves and one acorn extends into the right margin following the final line of text. To the right of this branch, a bird flies upward on extended wings. A vine with two loops grows from the first letter of "FINIS" and extends horizontally above the word.

component.illusobjdesc: At least four insects, perhaps beetles and one caterpillar, crawl along the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text. At least one further insect sits on the vine near the right margin. Below the vine and again near the right margin are three flying creatures.
At least four winged insects (some little more than dots) fly above the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text. The insect below "fury" at the end of line 2 is probably a butterfly.
A bird perches on the vine between lines 2 and 3 of the text, just below "of his" in line 2. Its wings are spread as though it were about to fly.
A bird flies upward and to the left on extended wings near the right margin of the plate, right of the branch following the final line of text.

A vine with one loop and an ivy-like leaf grows above the first letter of the first word ("The") in line 3 of the text. An oak or grape leaf descends from the first word in line 3 and into the far left margin.
A vine with two oak or grape leaves extends horizontally below "the vineyards" in line 2 of the text.
A large vine with slender leaves extends horizontally beneath line 2 of the text and descends, in the right margin, to line 8.

A large vine with ivy-like leaves extends from the first letter of "Los" in line 9 and runs horizontally between lines 8 and 9 of the text and divides into several branches in the right margin. One branch extends back to the left at line 6.
A branch bearing five oak leaves and one acorn extends into the right margin following the final line of text.
A vine with two loops grows from the first letter of "FINIS" and extends horizontally above the word.

lg.l: Shot from the heights of Enitharmon, before the trumpet blew!The words "before the trumpet blew!" were erased from the copper in the third state of the plate.
And in the vineyards of red France appear'd the light of his fury.
The sun glow'd fiery red!
The furious terrors flew around!
On golden chariots raging, with red wheels dropping with blood;
The Lions lash their wrathful tails!
The Tigers couch upon the prey & suck the ruddy tide:
And Enitharmon groans & cries in anguish and dismay,
Then Los arose his head he reard in snaky thunders clad:
And with a cry that shook all nature to the utmost pole,
Call'd all his sons to the strife of blood.
